title: Has Persistence Persisted in Private Equity? Evidence from Buyout and Venture Capital Funds
authors: Robert S. Harris, Tim Jenkinson, Steven N. Kaplan, Ruediger Stucke
keyPoints: Uses Burgiss institutional-quality dataset; Finds limited persistence when using information available at fundraising time; VC persistence stronger than buyout; Performance differs pre/post-2000
keyHypotheses: Performance persistence exists but may be declining; Investors cannot effectively identify top performers ex-ante
strengths: High-quality unbiased data; Addresses selection bias; Large sample size; Separates ex-ante vs ex-post information
weaknesses: U.S. focused; Limited to institutional investors; May miss recent vintage dynamics
citation: Harris, Robert S., Tim Jenkinson, Steven N. Kaplan, and Ruediger Stucke. "Has persistence persisted in private equity? Evidence from buyout and venture capital funds." NBER Working Paper 28109 (2020).
notes: Gold standard for PE performance measurement. Establishes methodology for unbiased performance evaluation.

title: Benchmarking the Returns to Venture
authors: Susan E. Woodward, Robert E. Hall
keyPoints: Created first comprehensive VC index using transaction-based valuations; Used repeat valuation model; Corrected for selection bias; Provides S&P 500 equivalent for VC
keyHypotheses: VC returns exhibit significant vintage year effects; Systematic index construction possible despite irregular transactions
strengths: Innovative methodology; Large dataset; Addresses selection bias; Creates investable index
weaknesses: Data may still have some selection bias; Limited to certain time period
citation: Woodward, Susan E., and Robert E. Hall. "Benchmarking the returns to venture." NBER Working Paper 10202 (2003).
notes: Foundational work for VC performance benchmarking. Pioneered transaction-based index construction.

title: The Risk and Return of Venture Capital
keyPoints: VC systematic risk much higher than previously estimated; Risk-adjusted returns close to market returns; Extreme positive skewness critical factor; Portfolio-level analysis essential
keyHypotheses: VC returns do not exceed public markets after proper risk adjustment; Skewness is key distinguishing factor
strengths: Rigorous risk adjustment methodology; Portfolio-level analysis; Addresses systematic risk properly
weaknesses: Limited dataset; May not capture all VC risk factors; Static risk model
citation: Cochrane, John H. "The risk and return of venture capital." Journal of financial economics 75, no. 1 (2005): 3-52.
notes: Fundamentally changed understanding of VC risk-return characteristics. Influenced asset allocation models.

title: Risk-Adjusting the Returns to Venture Capital
keyPoints: Developed generalized SDF approach for VC evaluation; Handles irregular timing and skewness; VC fund returns close to zero after fees; VC company investments earn positive abnormal returns
keyHypotheses: Standard PME methods inadequate for VC; Manager selection crucial for VC success
strengths: Methodologically rigorous; Handles VC-specific challenges; Separates fund vs company performance
weaknesses: Complex methodology; Requires sophisticated implementation; Limited practical adoption
citation: Korteweg, Arthur, and Stefan Nagel. "Risk-adjusting the returns to venture capital." NBER Working Paper 19347 (2013).
notes: Most rigorous framework for VC performance evaluation. Widely adopted by academic researchers.

title: Cyclicality, Performance Measurement, and Cash Flow Liquidity in Private Equity
authors: David T. Robinson, Berk A. Sensoy
keyPoints: Public and private equity waves move together; Strong vintage year effects; Cash flow timing affected by market cycles; Fundraising and investment patterns cyclical
keyHypotheses: Private equity performance systematically related to public market cycles; Vintage year timing critical
strengths: Large dataset; Clear cyclical patterns identified; Connects macro conditions to PE performance
weaknesses: Limited to correlation analysis; Doesn't fully explain causal mechanisms
citation: Robinson, David T., and Berk A. Sensoy. "Cyclicality, performance measurement, and cash flow liquidity in private equity." NBER Working Paper 17428 (2011).
notes: Established systematic relationship between public/private market cycles. Key reference for vintage year effects.

title: The Persistent Effect of Initial Success: Evidence from Venture Capital
authors: Shai Bernstein, Xavier Giroud, Richard Townsend
keyPoints: Initial investment conditions create persistent performance differences; Early-stage market conditions have lasting impact; Hot vintage years associated with lower returns; Effects persist throughout fund lifecycle
keyHypotheses: Initial success creates persistent advantages; Market timing effects are fundamental, not transitory
strengths: Comprehensive analysis of persistence mechanisms; Large sample; Long time series; Rigorous identification
weaknesses: Limited to VC; U.S. focused; May not capture recent market changes
citation: Bernstein, Shai, Xavier Giroud, and Richard R. Townsend. "The persistent effect of initial success: Evidence from venture capital." Journal of Financial Economics 137, no. 1 (2020): 231-248.
notes: Provides mechanism analysis for vintage year effects. Shows persistence is fundamental characteristic.

title: Return to Venture Capital in the Aggregate
authors: Shumiao Ouyang, Jiaheng Yu, Ravi Jagannathan
keyPoints: Analyzed 17,242 ventures from 1980-2006; Aggregate IRR of 22%; PME of 1.44; Top 5% drive all returns; Performance declines after 1999
keyHypotheses: VC returns highly concentrated in top performers; Aggregate performance positive but declining
strengths: Comprehensive dataset; Long time series; Addresses valuation bias; Clear performance attribution
weaknesses: Historical data only; Limited to venture-backed companies; U.S. focused
citation: Ouyang, Shumiao, Jiaheng Yu, and Ravi Jagannathan. "Return to venture capital in the aggregate." NBER Working Paper 27690 (2020).
notes: Most comprehensive analysis of aggregate VC returns. Highlights extreme concentration of performance.

title: Bias in the Reporting of Venture Capital Performance: The Disciplinary Role of FOIA
authors: Janet Kiholm Smith, Erin E. Smith
keyPoints: Selective reporting overstates VC returns by 4 percentage points; GPs report irregularly; FOIA-eligible LPs provide discipline; Self-reporting creates systematic upward bias
keyHypotheses: GP reporting behavior systematically biased; Transparency mechanisms can improve data quality
strengths: Novel identification strategy; Important policy implications; Quantifies bias magnitude
weaknesses: Limited to certain LPs; May not generalize broadly; Focuses on reporting rather than performance
citation: Smith, Janet Kiholm, and Erin E. Smith. "Bias in the Reporting of Venture Capital Performance: The Disciplinary Role of FOIA." Working Paper (2023).
notes: Important findings on data quality issues in VC research. Has implications for all historical performance studies.

title: Does the Case for Private Equity Still Hold?
keyPoints: Questions fundamental assumptions about PE value proposition; Superior returns vs public markets narrowing; Liquidity premiums not consistently justified; Operating improvements overstated
keyHypotheses: Traditional PE premises no longer hold; Market conditions have changed fundamental dynamics
strengths: Comprehensive analysis; Questions conventional wisdom; Recent data; Policy relevant
weaknesses: May be too pessimistic; Limited time series; Focused critique rather than alternative framework
citation: Lietz, Nori Gerardo, and Philipp Chvanov. "Does the Case for Private Equity Still Hold?." Harvard Business School Working Paper 24-066 (2024).
notes: Important contemporary critique of PE value proposition. Challenges industry assumptions.

title: Comparing Capital Allocation Efficiency in Public and Private Equity Markets
keyPoints: Public markets allocate capital more efficiently; Efficiency gap concentrated in late-stage private deals; Late-stage private generates less innovation; Information and governance mechanisms superior in public markets
keyHypotheses: Public markets superior at capital allocation; Private market advantages overstated
strengths: Novel research question; Comprehensive efficiency analysis; Policy implications; Challenges conventional wisdom
weaknesses: May not capture all private market benefits; Methodology limitations; Limited to certain metrics
citation: Sanati, Ali, and Ioannis Spyridopoulos. "Comparing Capital Allocation Efficiency in Public and Private Equity Markets." SSRN Working Paper 4403578 (2024).
notes: Challenges private market efficiency assumptions. Important for policy debates about market structure.

title: An Index for Venture Capital, 1987-2003
authors: Min Hwang, John M. Quigley, Susan E. Woodward
keyPoints: Built VC index using repeat valuation model; Corrected for selection bias; Used 50,734 funding events; Measured return and risk for VC; Enabled diversified portfolio analysis
keyHypotheses: VC index construction feasible despite irregular pricing; VC can be analyzed like other asset classes
strengths: Large dataset; Systematic methodology; Risk-return analysis; Portfolio theory application
weaknesses: Limited time period; Selection bias may remain; Methodology complex
citation: Hwang, Min, John M. Quigley, and Susan E. Woodward. "An index for venture capital, 1987–2003." Contributions in Economic Analysis & Policy 4, no. 1 (2005).
notes: Extends Woodward-Hall methodology. Important for portfolio allocation decisions.

title: Private Equity Performance: Returns, Persistence, and Capital Flows
keyPoints: First comprehensive study of PE performance using cash flows; Found performance persistence; Better funds raise more capital; VC more persistent than buyout; Net performance roughly equal to S&P 500
keyHypotheses: PE performance persists across funds; Market mechanisms work to allocate capital to better performers
strengths: Pioneering methodology; Large sample; Addresses key questions; Influential findings
weaknesses: Limited time period; Data quality issues; May not capture modern dynamics
citation: Kaplan, Steven N., and Antoinette Schoar. "Private equity performance: returns, persistence, and capital flows." The Journal of Finance 60, no. 4 (2005): 1791-1823.
notes: Seminal paper establishing PE performance evaluation methodology. Most cited work in field.

title: 2025 Outlook: Private Equity & Venture Capital
authors: Andrea Auerbach, Scolet Ma, Sharad Todi
keyPoints: Expect PI performance improvement; Overinvestment effects from 2021-22 receding; Individual investor access growing; Continuation vehicles becoming primary exit path; Asian markets increasing activity
keyHypotheses: Private investment performance will heal itself; Market structure changes affecting exit dynamics
strengths: Industry expertise; Current market analysis; Practical insights; Forward-looking
weaknesses: Industry perspective; Limited academic rigor; Potential bias toward positive outlook
citation: Auerbach, Andrea, Scolet Ma, and Sharad Todi. "2025 Outlook: Private Equity & Venture Capital." Cambridge Associates (2025).
notes: Current industry perspective from leading investment consultant. Provides contemporary market view.

title: Global Private Markets Report 2025: Braced for Shifting Weather
authors: Alexander Edlich, Christopher Croke, Fredrik Dahlqvist, Warren Teichner
keyPoints: Mixed conditions in 2024; Fundraising fell to lowest since 2016; Capital deployment increased double digits; Geopolitical instability critical challenge; AI advancement compelling new capabilities
keyHypotheses: Market conditions remain uneven; Technology innovation driving value creation; Structural changes affecting traditional patterns
strengths: Comprehensive industry analysis; Global perspective; Current data; Strategic insights
weaknesses: Consulting perspective; Limited academic methodology; Industry bias
citation: Edlich, Alexander, et al. "Global Private Markets Report 2025: Braced for Shifting Weather." McKinsey & Company (2025).
notes: Comprehensive industry analysis from leading consulting firm. Shows current market dynamics affecting vintage year performance.

title: Private Equity Outlook 2025: Is a Recovery Starting to Take Shape?
keyPoints: PE investments and exits reversed two-year decline; Fundraising lagged; Largest funds capturing most capital; Winner funds need clear strategy and consistent performance
keyHypotheses: Recovery beginning but uneven; Performance differentiation widening; Manager selection increasingly critical
strengths: Industry analysis; Performance insights; Forward-looking perspective
weaknesses: Industry bias; Limited methodology disclosure; Consulting perspective
citation: "Private Equity Outlook 2025: Is a Recovery Starting to Take Shape?" Bain & Company Global Private Equity Report (2025).
notes: Shows current industry dynamics and manager differentiation trends affecting vintage year analysis.
